channel.title: BLOG on Katherine Wood
channel.description: Recent content in BLOG on Katherine Wood

item.title: What is it like to run a Registered Replication?
item.description: Registered replications are generally considered the gold standard of replication studies. What does it take to actually run one?

item.title: CORVIDS 2.0: Faster, more stable, and now on Windows
CORVIDS: A provably-complete data reconstruction tool
item.description: Using the constraints of Likert-scale data to fully reconstruct it.

item.title: Improving a data visualization
item.description: There’s a point at which more information yields negative returns.

item.title: Pre-screen MTurk workers with custom qualifications
item.description: How to set up custom qualification tests to screen MTurk workers.

item.title: Getting started with the Mechanical Turk API
item.description: How to get set up with AWS and Mechanical Turk.

item.title: Starter tips on sharing data and analysis scripts
item.description: Getting your materials ready for public release.

item.title: Considerations when writing a preregistration if you're new to all this
item.description: How do you know where to start?

item.title: Intro to unit testing in R
item.description: The best way to know if something works is to test it.

item.title: Intro to R Notebooks
item.description: Combine executable code, math formatting, and nice markdown in one easy place.

item.title: Data in the raw: Violin plots
item.description: Violin plots are a way to present more information about your raw data.

item.title: Intro to Bootstrapping
item.description: Bootstrapping is a powerful and intuitive technique.

item.title: 5 Minute Simulation: Variation in effect size estimates
item.description: How much variability can you expect from the effect size estimate in a single study?

item.title: Open Science in Practice
item.description: A look inside an open science workflow.
